In this thesis, a comparison is made between the performance of Alamouti space-time block codes and time-reversed space-time block codes with 16-APSK to solve the two-antenna problem. Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, BYU Master of Science

The maximum likelihood decoder/detector for Alamouti-encoded 16-APSK is a sequence detector operating on a trellis with a large number of states. A practical state-reduction technique is presented. The results produce a trellis with 256 states and a small loss in bit error rate performance as long as the delay difference is not too big. The decoder/detector for the time-reversed space time block requires only waveform manipulations and channel matched filtering in the case where the two channels are simple delays. For the more general case of multipath propagation between the two transmit antennas and the receiver, the decoder/detector requires an equalizer; simulation results using a channel pair measured at a test range show that the decoder/detector is capable of achieving near AWGN performance with a modest equalizer.

CHAPTER 1. INTRODUCTION

sections.heading: 1.1 The Two Antenna Problem
sections.text:
Aeronautical mobile telemetry (AMT) is an air-to-ground radio link carrying mea-
surements from an airborne test article to a ground station. The measurements (telemetry) contain all the information required for flight test engineers to ensure safety of flight and to determine if the test article meets performance requirements. To increase the spatial coverage on fixed- and rotary-winged test articles, two antennas are often used to account for blockage by the fuselage. The most common configuration is to place one antenna on the top of the fuselage and the other on the bottom as shown in Figure 1.1.
The earliest implementations of this configuration transmitted the same RF telemetry
signal from both antennas using a power splitter connected to the telemetry transmitter output. This implementation created a simple antenna array defined by the two antennas. An example of the radiation gain pattern created by two antennas is shown in Figure 1.2. The result was a sequence of link outages when the test article executed a turn: the drop outs occurred when the propagation path from the test article to the ground station was through one of the nulls. When bit rates increased beyond 5 Mbits/s, the link was difficult to maintain even when the propagation path was through one of the high-gain lobes. In this case, the link outages are the result of self-interference resulting from the difference in propagation delays between the two antennas and the ground station. Collectively, the problems associated with transmitting the same signal from two antennas separated by several wavelengths is called the two-antenna problem [1]–[6].
The use of space-time coding to solve the two-antenna problem was pioneered in [1]
for QPSK. The idea was applied to the continuous phase modulations (CPMs) defined in the AMT standards IRIG-106 [7] in [2], [3], [5], [6].
1
There has been recent interest in adopting non-binary linear modulations in AMT to
improve spectral efficiency. To be viable, the modulation must have a relatively low peak-toaverage power ratio so that the required output backoff in the RF power amplifier does not significantly reduce operating range of the radio link. The PAPR/backoff tradeoff is common in satellite communications. The direct video broadcast, satellite second generation (DVBS2) standard [8] addresses the PAPR issue by defining constellations whose points lie on one circle (QPSK and 8-PSK), two circles (16-APSK), and three circles (32-APSK). Because
2
16-APSK and 32-APSK constellations achieve a reasonable tradeoff between peak-to-average power ratio and throughput, 16-APSK has been considered for use in AMT [9]. The authors of [10] explored the use of 16- and 32-APSK with turbo codes in the AMT. The results showed that 16-APSK with rate-4/5 turbo codes is able to achieve spectral efficiency approximately 3 times that of the uncoded CPM in IRIG 106 called SOQPSK-TG. SOQPSK-TG stands for shaped offset QPSK, version “TG”. Despite its name, SOQPSK-TG is a CPM with a modulation index of 1/2, a constrained ternary alphabet, and a frequency pulse spanning 8 bit times.
A natural question in the evolution of AMT modulations is to investigate the per-
formance of 16-APSK in solving the two-antenna problem. Alamouti’s space-time block code (A-STBC) [11] and Lindskog’s time-reversed space-time block code (TR-STBC) [12] are investigated in this thesis. The justification for these two (and only these two) is based on the following observations. The motivation for A-STBC is the fact that it was proven in [1] that Alamouti’s space-time block code solves the two-antenna problem using QPSK. The impact of a differential delay was not addressed in [1] but is examined in the authors’ conference article for 16-APSK [4] and summarized in Chapter 2. The maximum likelihood decoder/detector for A-STBC in the presence of a differential delay is a sequence detector whose complexity can be prohibitive for large constellations with bandlimited pulse shaping. The motivation for TR-STBC is its Alamouti-like structure for symbol sequences and the ability to incorporate parallel equalizers after a waveform orthogonalization step. The different propagation delays from the two transmit antennas are treated as channels whose outputs need to be equalized. The use of simple linear equalizers avoids the complex trellis required by the A-STBC decoder/detector. Most of the work on STBCs following [11], [12] explore orthogonal space-time codes or quasi-orthogonal space time codes for a larger number of transmit and receive antennas. In AMT, the problem is confined to two transmit antennas and one receive antenna; the larger codes are not needed.
The results of this work are the following.
1. The maximum likelihood detector for A-STBC in the presence of a differential delay is
a sequence detector whose Viterbi algorithm implementation requires a trellis with too many states to be of any practical interest. A state-reduction technique, based on a
3
simple approximation of the pulse shape autocorrelation function, is shown to produce an enormous reduction in the trellis size at the cost of a fraction of a dB loss in bit error rate performance. The performance loss increases with increasing differential delay; this favorable trade-off works as long as the differential delay is not too large.
2. The TR-STBC is reformulated in the continous-time waveform domain. This is per-
formed to derive a filter-based version of the TR-STBC decoder/detector to replace the linear operator formulation in [12]. The filter-based version is preferable for long data sequences. The filter-based version comprises three steps: waveform partition, waveform decoding, equalization and detection. For the case where the propagation paths from the two transmit antennas are simple delays, we show that the first two steps are all that is required; equalization is not required. Computer simulations show that the bit error rate performance of the TR-STBC decoder/detector coincides with the 16-APSK bit error rate performance in additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN), and achieves this performance for all differential delays of practical interest. TR-STBC is robust with differential delay in a way that A-STBC is not.
3. In addition to the computational complexity advantage and bit error rate performance
advantages, TR-STBC is capable of operating in a multipath propagation environment with the same complexity. A-STBC is theoretically able to operate in a multipath environment, but the required complexity renders the approach infeasible. The effectiveness of TR-STBC on a pair of real channels measured at Edwards AFB, USA is presented. The results show that a simple linear equalizer is capable of achieving a bit error rate performance equivalent to that of 16-APSK in the AWGN environment.
The contributions of this work are listed below.
• The A-STBC and TR-STBC methods have been used on continuous phase modulations
such as SO-QPSK and ARTM CPM. The significance with this thesis is that these methods are used for 16-APSK, which is a linear phase modulation.

• Another key component to this work is that the simulations are performed with a
differential delay which is unique to AMT. This differential delay has not been explored for linear phase modulations using these encoding methods.
• The two methods, A-STBC and TR-STBC, are simulated and analyzed for 16-APSK.
It is concluded that the TR-STBC method triumphs over the A-STBC method when it comes to the two-antenna problem in AMT for 16-APSK in the presence of a differential delay.
This thesis is organized as follows. The problem formulation is presented in Sec-
tion 1.2. The application of the Alamouti space-time block code is described in Chapter 2 and the time-reversed space-time block code is developed in Chapter 3. Conclusions are discussed in Chapter 4.

sections.text:
A block diagram of the system corresponding to Figure 1.1 is illustrated in Figure 1.3.
User symbols denoted I(k) are drawn from the 16-APSK constellation shown in Figure 1.4. The space-time encoding techniques investigated here are applied to the user symbols. The result is two parallel symbol streams J0(k) and J1(k) both of which also comprise 16-APSK symbols. Pulse shaping is applied to create the complex-valued low-pass equivalent waveforms. The pulse shape p(t) is a square-root Nyquist pulse shape [13] with support on T1 ≤ t ≤ T2.

The propagation channels are represented by LTI systems with impulse responses
c0(t) and c1(t). Our primary interest is with the channels
c0(t) = g0δ(t− τ0) c1(t) = g1δ(t− τ1) (1.1)
where g0 and g1 are complex-valued propagation gains, and τ0 and τ1 are the delays, respectively, of the channels between s0(t) and s1(t) and the receiver. This case is noted in Figure 1.3. The reason for the more generalized form used in the figure is explained in Chapter 3.
The received signal is given by

The received signal is passed through a filter matched to the pulse shape and sampled at the four instants required to compute the branch metric (2.29). The number of states required for ML detection is an important consideration. For
16-APSK, M = 16 and the number of states is 162L = 256L. The number of states grows rapidly with L. As an example L = 2 requires a trellis with 65,536 states. Consequently, L > 1 is impractical. Unfortunately, pulse shapes with good spectral containment are longer than 2 symbol times. For this reason, a non-optimal approach using L′ < L is explored.

As will be shown in Section 3.3, L′ = 1 is a very good approximation that presents a desirable complexity/performance tradeoff as long as ∆τ/Ts is not too big. The assumption 0 ≤ ∆τ < Ts is supported by the size of test articles and bit rates commonly encountered in aeronautical mobile telemetry as explained in Section IV of [5]. The approximation L′ = 0 is also explored in the next section.
It should be noted that as the excess bandwidth decreases, the temporal sidelobes of

sections.heading: 2.3 Numerical Example
sections.text:
Computer simulations were performed to assess the bit error rate (BER) performance
of the A-STBC system. For the simulations, the square-root raised-cosine pulse shape with

50% excess bandwidth and a span of 12 symbols (T1 = −6Ts, T2 = 6Ts) was used [13]. The 16-APSK constellation parameters were R2/R1 = 2.75, θ1 = π/4 and θ2 = π/12 (cf., Figure 1.4). The simulation uses (1.1) for the channels with g0 = +1 and g1 = −1. The phase difference of π produces the deep nulls observed when transmitting the same signal from both antennas (i.e., “the two-antenna problem”).
The BER simulation results for A-STBC for ∆τ = 0.1Ts, 0.2Ts and for L ′ = 0, 1
are plotted in Figure 2.3. Also shown in the figure for reference is the BER performance of uncoded 16-APSK in the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) environment. The abscissa is the received “SNR” α21Eb/N0 where
α21 = |g0|2 + |g1|2. (2.31)
The pulse shape autocorrelation function xTs(ℓTs+∆τ) is plotted in Figure 2.2. As explained earlier in this chapter, L′ = 1 is a good approximation for this pulse shape as long as ∆τ is not too large. The impact of this assumption on BER performance is shown in the figure.
21
For ∆τ = 0.1Ts, the BER performance loss (relative to the AWGN case) at 10 −5 is a fraction of a dB; for ∆τ = 0.2Ts, the BER performance is only slightly worse. Investigating relatively small values for ∆τ is justified by the geometry (size of typical test articles) and commonly encountered bit rates (5 to 20 Mbits/s) as explained in [5, Section IV]. The interesting feature here is that the approximation used for state reduction renders the BER performance a function of ∆τ . This is because the approximation error grows as ∆τ increases.
Also included in Figure 2.3 is the case L′ = 0. This case ignores the memory from one
Alamouti block to the next and eliminates the need for a sequence search. The simulation results show that removing the sequence detector profoundly impacts the BER performance: the performance loss is about 1.5 dB for ∆τ = 0.1Ts. For ∆τ = 0.2Ts, a BER floor at about 2.5× 10−4 is observed. (The floor occurs at higher values of received SNR than displayed in the plot.)

sections.heading: 3.1 TR-STBC Encoding
sections.text:
TR-STBC encoding closely follows Alamouti encoding except that the encoder oper-
ates on blocks of data instead of Alamouti’s symbol-by-symbol encoding, and performs a time reversal and complex conjugation where Alamouti encoding performs a complex conjugation. To this end, the TR-STBC encoder partitions the input data symbols into non-overlapping blocks of block 2N data symbols denoted
I(0), I(1), . . . , I(2N − 1).
The TR-STBC encoder partitions the block of 2N symbols into two subblocks of N symbols each. The two subblocks are denoted I0(k) and I1(k) for k = 0, . . . , N − 1 where
I0(k) = I(k) I1(k) = I(N + k). (3.1)
23
The encoder produces two encoded sequences denoted J0(n) and J1(n) for 0 ≤ n ≤ 2N − 1 where
J0(n) = I0(n) 0 ≤ n ≤ N − 1I∗1 (2N − 1− n) N ≤ n ≤ 2N − 1 (3.2)
J1(n) = I1(n) 0 ≤ n ≤ N − 1−I∗0 (2N − 1− n) N ≤ n ≤ 2N − 1. (3.3) The waveforms produced after application of the pulse shaping filter are transmitted in two non-overlapping time intervals. The waveforms transmitted during the first interval T1 ≤ t ≤ (N − 1)Ts + T2 are
s0(t) = N−1∑ k=0 J0(k)p(t− kTs)
s1(t) = N−1∑ k=0 J1(k)p(t− kTs). (3.4)
The waveforms transmitted during the second intervalNTs+T1+Tg ≤ t ≤ (2N−1)Ts+T2+Tg are
s0(t) = 2N−1∑ k=N J0(k)p(t− kTs − Tg)
s1(t) = 2N−1∑ k=N J1(k)p(t− kTs − Tg). (3.5)
The two time intervals are separated by a guard interval of duration Tg whose necessity is explained in the next section.

y1(t) = h ∗ 1(−t)⋆ [ N−1∑ k=0 J0(k)h0(t− kTs) + N−1∑ k=0 J1(k)h1(t− kTs) + z0(t) ]
+h0(t)⋆ [ N−1∑ k=0 J∗0 (2N − 1− k)h∗0(−t+ kTs)

(3.19)
Multiplying out the terms in (3.19) gives

Using the substitution found in (3.15) and placing it in (3.20) yields

+ N−1∑ k=0 J0(k)x01(t− kTs) + N−1∑ k=0 J∗1 (2N − 1− k)x01(t− kTs)

Another simplification can be made by recognizing that J∗0 (2N − 1 − k) = I1(k) = J1(k), J0(k) = I0(k), and J ∗ 1 (2N − 1− k) = −I0(k), all for 0 ≤ k ≤ N − 1 [recall (3.2) and (3.3)]. This simplifies the second term and cancels out the third and fourth terms of (3.16), leaving

The noise terms v0(t) and v1(t) are the contributions to y0(t) and y1(t) due to additive

E{vℓ(t+ τ)v∗m(t)} = 2N0 [x00(τ) + x11(τ)] ℓ = m0 ℓ ̸= m. (3.24) The rest of this subsection deals with showing how (3.24) is true. − ∫ ∫

Because the noise z(t) is proper, E{z(t + τ)z(t)} = 0 and E{z∗(t + τ)z∗(t)} = 0. Thus the second and third terms can be eliminated, which changes (3.28) to
E{v0(t+ τ)v∗0(t)} = ∫ ∫ h∗0(u− t− τ)h0(λ− t)E{z(u)z∗(λ)}du dλ
+ ∫ ∫ h1(t+ τ − u′)h∗1(t− λ′)E{z∗(−u′ − Ts)z(−λ′ − Ts)}du′ dλ′. (3.29)
Evaluating the remaining expectations yields
E{v0(t+ τ)v∗0(t)} = ∫ ∫ 2N0δ(u− λ)h∗0(u− t− τ)h0(λ− t)du dλ
+ ∫ ∫ 2N0δ(u ′ − λ′)h1(t+ τ − u′)h∗1(t− λ′)du′ dλ′. (3.30)

From here the sifting property can be applied to the equation:

= 2N0 ∫ h∗0(λ− t− τ)h0(λ− t)dλ+ 2N0 ∫ h1(t+ τ − λ′)h∗1(t− λ′)dλ′. (3.31)

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Equalization and Detection
sections.text:
In preparation for a discrete-time equalizer, Ts-spaced samples of y0(t) and y1(t) are
taken to produce
y0(nTs) = N−1∑ k=0 J0(k) [x00((n− k)Ts) + x11((n− k)Ts)] + v0(nTs) (3.48) y1(nTs) = N−1∑ k=0 J1(k) [x00((n− k)Ts) + x11((n− k)Ts)] + v1(nTs). (3.49)
The Ts-spaced samples define a discrete-time equivalent channel relating the input symbol streams to the samples.
Equation (3.48) defines the relationship between the sequence J0(n) and y0(nTs). The
channel relating the two is the equivalent channel
heq(nTs) = x00(nTs) + x11(nTs). (3.50)
35
The additive noise term in (3.48) is a vector of complex-valued normal random variables with zero mean and autocorrelation function
E{v0((n+m)Ts)v∗0(nTs)} = 2N0heq(mTs). (3.51)
Note that only sequence J0(n) is involved in (3.48). Similarly, (3.49) defines the relationship between J1(n) and y1(nTs); the relationship is defined by the equivalent channel (3.50); and the additive noise is a vector of complex-valued normal random variables with identical statistics to those of v0(nTs).
The “orthogonalization” of J0(n) and J1(n) is achieved by the cascade of the encoding
and the procedure that produced y0(t) and y1(t) from r0(t) and r1(t). The orthogonalization can only be achieved if the received segments r0(t) and r1(t) do not possess any temporal overlap. This is the purpose of the guard interval Tg. The illustration in Figure 3.2 shows that the guard interval must satisfy
Tg + Ts ≥ T2 − T1 + Tc. (3.52)
The guard interval must take into account not only the spreading due to the channel but also the temporal support of the pulse shape. The guard interval may be realized by inserting a blank period between the transmission in the first interval and the transmission in the second interval. Alternatively (and the preferred approach in AMT) a sequence of known symbols may be inserted between J0(N − 1) and J0(N) and between J1(N − 1) and J1(N) (cf., Figure 3.2). A guard interval of the same length must also be inserted between the end of transmission for J0(2N − 1) and J1(2N − 1) and first symbol of the subsequent block. This guard interval may be created in the same way as described above. Periodic insertion of the guard interval between subblocks and between blocks ensures that each subblock can be processed independently of both the other subblock in the same block or of subblocks in other blocks. This is why, in the analysis above, the detection of a single block is justified.
The parallel discrete-time equivalent channels define Ungerboeck observation models
for equalization and/or detection. A number of alternatives may be used.
36
• Maximum-likelihood detection of J0(n) from y0(nTs) may be performed using the
Viterbi algorithm described in [15]. Here, in the sense maximum likelihood sequence detection performs “equalization,” equalization and detection are performed simultaneously.
• A filter-based equalizer [14] (such as the MMSE or decision feedback equalizer) whose
design incorporates the noise correlation may be applied to create decision variables that are used by a simple symbol-by-symbol detector.
• Noise whitening may be applied to the Ungerboeck observation model to create the
Forney observation model [16]. Maximum likelihood sequence detection using the Viterbi algorithm as described in [16] may be used to perform simultaneous equalization and detection.
• A filter based-equalizer based on the Forney observation model may be used.
The same options apply to the equalization and detection of J1(n) from y1(nTs).
Of special interest is the case where the channel impulse responses are given by (1.1).
From Figure 1.3, it is shown that

CHAPTER 4. CONCLUSIONS
Two methods are presented for solving the two-antenna problem in aeronautical mo-
bile telemetry for 16-APSK. The first method uses the Alamouti space-time block code. Because the delays from the two transmit antennas are different, the decoder/detector is a sequence detector. The maximum likelihood (ML) sequence detector was derived and shown to be too complex for a realistic implementation. A state reduction, realized through a simple approximation of the pulse shape autocorrelation function (as shown in Figure 2.2), was shown to provide good performance (measured by the loss in BER performance relative to the AWGN case) as long as the differential delay ∆τ is not too big (Figure 2.3).
The second method applies Lindskog’s time-reversed space-time block code. The
decoder treats the delays as channels to be equalized and comprises waveform manipulations followed by parallel equalizers operating on identical equivalent discrete-time channels. For the case where the channels are simple delays, the waveform manipulations alone solve the two-antenna problem as shown in Figure 3.4. TR-STBC is capable of handling more complex scenarios and was demonstrated to be effective at equalizing a pair of multipath channels measured at Edwards AFB (see Figure 3.7).
The importance of these results is that these encoding methods have been simulated
for other modulations that are continuous phase modulations, but they have not previously been simulated for 16-APSK. These methods have also not been explored in the presence of differential delays for linear phase modulations which occur in AMT.
Given the obvious complexity advantage of TR-STBC over A-STBC in the AMT
setting together with the fact that TR-STBC can easily handle more general situations, TR-STBC is the preferred solution to the two-antenna problem.

The next steps that could be taken for this work are to incorporate more components
into the block diagrams. For the A-STBC method, estimates of the channel gains and the differential delay are needed to compute symbol sequence estimates from the Viterbi Algorithm. In the TR-STBC method, there must be a way to estimate the channel to process the data in the receiver and equalizers.
